issues.description: The UML in the problem statement specifies Farm.addAnimal(animal: Animal):boolean (i.e., a boolean return type), but the provided solution implements addAnimal as public void addAnimal(Animal animal). The template repository also does not provide an addAnimal implementation (left as a TODO). This mismatch between the UML and the solution can confuse students about the expected method signature and return type (should they implement a boolean-returning method or a void method?).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the expected signature consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement UML to declare addAnimal(animal: Animal):void (and mention in the text that addAnimal simply adds the animal with no return value), or (B) change the solution/template to implement public boolean addAnimal(Animal animal) (for example returning true on successful addition). Option A is simpler and matches the current textual description; apply the chosen change to both the UML in problem_statement.md and any tests/instructions so students clearly know to implement a void addAnimal method.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Farm.addAnimal(animal: Animal): boolean, but the provided implementation (and template usage) treats addAnimal as a void method (template Main calls farm.addAnimal(...) and solution implements public void addAnimal(Animal)). This mismatch between the problem-spec UML signature and the code can confuse students about the expected method contract (should the method return a boolean or not?) and may lead to attempts to implement or test the method with the wrong signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method contract consistent across artifacts. Either update the UML in the problem statement to declare addAnimal(Animal a): void (matching template and solution), or change the template and solution to implement addAnimal(Animal a): boolean (for example, implement `public boolean addAnimal(Animal animal) { return animals.add(animal); }`). Prefer whichever matches the intended tests/assignment instructions; document the chosen signature in the textual task description to avoid ambiguity.
